dt: {bc}occurring or developing at a faster rate than usual

dt.t: an industry that is growing at an {wi}accelerated{/wi} pace

dt: {bc}designed to be completed in a shorter length of time than usual

shortdef: occurring or developing at a faster rate than usual
designed to be completed in a shorter length of time than usual

dt.t: The pace of change has {wi}accelerated{/wi} in recent months.

dt: {bc}to progress from grade to grade more rapidly than usual {bc}to follow a speeded-up educational program
{bc}to bring about at an earlier time
{bc}to hasten the progress or development of
{bc}to enable (a student) to complete a course in less than usual time
{bc}to speed up (something, such as a course of study)

et: borrowed from Latin {it}accelerātus{/it}, past participle of {it}accelerāre{/it} "to add speed to, hasten the occurrence of, go quickly," from {it}ad-{/it} {et_link|ad-|ad-} + {it}celerāre{/it} "to hasten," verbal derivative of {it}celer{/it} "swift, speedy," perhaps going back to {it}*keli-li-/ri-{/it}, derivative from the Indo-European base of Greek {it}kélomai, kelésthai{/it} "urge, exhort," {it}kelēt-, kélēs{/it} "swift horse, charger"
shortdef: to move faster : to gain speed
to progress from grade to grade more rapidly than usual : to follow a speeded-up educational program
to bring about at an earlier time
